description:
Magnolia sinica, also known as the Chinese Magnolia, is a species of flowering plant in the family Magnoliaceae. It is native to southwestern China, primarily found in the Yunnan and Sichuan provinces.

Magnolia sinica is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree, typically reaching a height of 10-20 meters. The leaves are simple, oblong-lanceolate in shape, and measure 10-20 cm in length. The flowers are large, showy, and fragrant, with 9-12 white or pale pink tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals).

The plant is known for its impressive floral display, with the flowers blooming in early spring before the leaves emerge. The fruits are cone-like structures, comprised of numerous follicles that contain the seeds.

Magnolia sinica is a valuable ornamental species, widely cultivated for its aesthetic appeal and used in landscaping and horticulture. It is also of interest for its potential medicinal properties, as various parts of the plant have been traditionally used in Chinese herbal medicine.

The species is classified as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List, as it has a relatively wide distribution and is not currently facing significant threats to its populations.
